Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: July 23, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: G4S agreed to pay $450,000 in settlement of alleged violations of the false claims and consumer protection acts by falsely certifying it had timely paid its subcontractors on public works projects while actually delaying payments so it could show higher cash balances on its financial statements.
Info Source: https://wayback.archive-it.org/1101/20181226033639/https://www.mass.gov/news/telecommunications-contractor-to-pay-450000-for-making-false-payment-certifications-to

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: September 3, 2019 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address.

Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20101110042124/http://www.ag.ny.gov/media_center/2009/feb/feb12a_09.html

Description: G4S Secure Solutions NV, a Belgian security firm, agreed to plead guilty for its role in a conspiracy to rig bids, allocate customers and fix prices for defense-related security services, including a multimillion-dollar contract issued in 2020 to provide security services to the U.S. Department of Defense for military bases and installations in Belgium.
